author: xmine64
body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

Hey, using a network inspector, I realized that Powershell sends a request to Microsoft servers on startup and I guess it's an update check, because once I get a notification on startup that there's a new Powershell version available. However, I don't like this behavior, and as I installed it from Microsoft Store I'll know if there's an update from there. I have some delay when I start Powershell (It's slow to show prompt and execute first command) so if there was a way to disable this it would help to reduce this delay.

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

_No response_

comments.author: JanRK
comments.body:
This is what we are using in docker to stop telemetry (including version check). If you are on windows, I think you need to set the envs on both system and user.
```
ENV POWERSHELL_CLI_TELEMETRY_OPTOUT=1 \
        POWERSHELL_TELEMETRY_OPTOUT=1 \
        POWERSHELL_UPDATECHECK=Off \
        POWERSHELL_UPDATECHECK_OPTOUT=1 \
        DOTNET_CLI_TELEMETRY_OPTOUT=1 \
        DOTNET_TELEMETRY_OPTOUT=1 \
        COMPlus_EnableDiagnostics=0
```

comments.author: xmine64
comments.body:
Thank you @JanRK I'll add them to environment variables.

Update: After doing that, Powershell really launches faster.

According to [this](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/main/docs/workflow/debugging/coreclr/debugging.md#disabling-managed-attachdebugging) page setting `COMPlus_EnableDiagnostics` to `0` disables debugger on .NET Core/.NET 5/.NET 6 apps. I had this problem. If you are a .NET programmer don't add it to environment variables or you'll have problem.
